_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This revision of the Fort James LLC Camas Mill Risk Management plan is being made to document the reduction of hazardous chemical use at the mill.  The use of elemental chlorine has been eliminated at all the mill's bleaching lines.  The water disinfection system has also been changed to eliminate the need for the use of elemental chlorine.

ES.1  FORT JAMES LLC POLICIES ON ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION

Corporate Commitment

The management and employees of the Fort James LLC Camas Mill are committed to responsible stewardship of the environment, protection of the community, protection of employee health, and assurance of product safety.  Management systems have been developed, and are continually upgraded, to prevent the release of regulated substances, especially in locations which may cause detrimental effects to employees, the community or the environment.  

ES.2  DESCRIPTION OF THE CAMAS MILL. REGULATED SUBSTANCES AND REGULATED PROCESSES

Mill Description

The Fort James Camas Mill is located on 185 acres adjacent to the Columbia River in Clark County, Washington.  The mill first began operation in 1883, when it was constructed to supply newsprint for the Portland area.

The mill currently produces cut size, tissue, toweling and communication papers.  Raw materials in the form of wood chips, sawdust, waste paper and pulp arrive from all over the Northwest by truck, barge and rail car.

The Camas Mill uses the kraft pulping process to convert wood chips and sawdust into brown kraft pulp.  The pulp is then bleached in either of two bleach plants, neither of which uses elemental chlorine.  Many of the paper grades produced contain a blend of this pulp and secondary fiber recycled from waste paper.

Paper is made on eight different machines.  Six of the machines produce towel and tissue grades; two produce communication papers.  The oldest machine dates from 1910, and the newest from 1984.  Daily production ranges from 30 tons per day on the smallest to over 600 t

ons per day on the newest and largest.  Rolls of paper from machines are sold directly to printers and converters or further processed on the mill site into finished goods.  The mill also operates a pulp dryer to produce baled pulp for internal use and for sale to external customers.

Waste water is treated and discharged to the main channel of the Columbia River.  The clarifier, aeration ponds and waste fiber landfill are located on Lady Island, a 476 acre site separated from the mill by the Camas Slough.

The Camas Mill employs 1175 people from the local area as well as from the neighboring cities of Vancouver, Washington and Portland, Oregon.  Most processes operate 24 hours a day, 7 days per week and 52 weeks per year.  Production equipment is shut down during scheduled maintenance downs for maintenance, or curtailed during periods of low market demand.  The entire facility is shut down periodically for large scale maintenance and cleaning.

Regulated Substances and Processes

The Camas Mill stores two chemicals above the threshold limits of 40 CFR 68.130. 

Chlorine is used in the production of chlorine dioxide in the mill's Lurgi generator; one 90-ton rail car is connected to the system at all times.  Chlorine is also stored in a 450 gallon day tank.

Chlorine dioxide is produced in the Lurgi and R8 chlorine dioxide generators for use in the mill bleach plants.  The chemical is produced as a 0.9% solution; for purposes of this report, the concentration used for calculation of worst case and alternate case scenarios  is 1.4%, as analyses have shown that solution concentration may reach that level at certain parts of the process.


ES.3  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AT THE CAMAS MILL

The Camas Mill Accident Prevention program has been developed to comply with 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, as administered by the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA).

The Process Safety Management program, or PS

M, is comprised of fourteen (14) different elements, each of which contributes to the health and safety of the workers whose jobs require them to be in direct contact with hazardous chemicals.  The mill has two qualified PSM coordinators managing the program.  In addition to the two coordinator positions, a Process Safety Management Steering Committee meets once per month.  The team is made up of hourly and salaried employees and oversees the implementation of all aspects of the PSM program at the mill.


ES.7  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM AT THE CAMAS MILL

The Camas Mill maintains a comprehensive written emergency response program, which is intended to protect worker and public safety and the environment.  The program includes plans and procedures for responding to a wide range of events, caused either naturally or accidentally, that could result in a release of a regulated substance.  Procedures are also included for responding to a potential fire or explosion involving  flammable substances.

The mill employs a full-time emergency response team, which is fully qualified to respond to all hazardous materials events.  Mill personnel are trained in the use of Integrated Command System protocols for responding to emergency situations, and drills are conducted annually to test the ability to respond to spill events.

The overall emergency response plan is coordinated with the City of Camas Fire Department.  This coordination includes periodic meetings with local emergency response officials, local government officials, independent response contractors and industry representatives.
